elements.text: [Part One]
Hiss, crackle.

[OC]: Fighter carrier Valiant. Comms package alpha seven zero four. Transmitting at ship time thirteen forty hours, January 15th 2197. Executive officer Moore reporting. Captain Tanya Oswin commanding. Current position Pluto orbital path. Arrival on schedule. No enemy sightings, but advance scans indicate hostile raider activity during late December. Condition of high battle alert maintained. Standard defence drills in progress, rigorous schedule. We must be ready for the fight when it comes. Package ends.
[Tannoy]: Attention, attention. This Operations Control. All Damocles pilots are instructed to maintain stand-by alert status. Maintain stand-by alert status.
Stand-by alert status? Now that makes a change.
Bell rings.
What? Who? O'Keefe, is that you pratting about? (gasps) No. No, please, don't. I don't want to.
Voices in distance. A door slides open.
Did you lot hear that?
What, Operations? Stand-by alert status.
You didn't hear it.
Hear what, old son?
Ooo, Armstrong's got the jitters.
Laughter.
He's falling apart as we speak. Call the medics. Whoops, smash, too late. There goes his bottle. Is that what you were looking for, Maxilli?
Has anyone ever told you you're hilarious, Hayman? No, I'm not surprised.
Armstrong, you look like you're going to throw up, man. What exactly did you hear?
I, I don't really. Like a bell, but I felt it was like it was
Bong! Ask not for whom the bell tolls, it tolls for thee.
No, it was like, not like that. It was
[Tannoy]: Attention, attention. This is an Operations alert. Scramble. Scramble.
Come on, Armstrong, don't just stand there, move!
What? But I
Move it!
Damocles Squadron now scrambling, Captain.
Thank you, XO. I take it the clock's running?
It is, ma'am. If they don't get space-borne in less than four minutes, I will personally fry their asses.
Thank you, XO.
O'Keefe has ignition, now Bold.
They're good, but then they always are. What about Armstrong? He's usually first.
Maxilli, Hayman and Craddock now have ignition.
No Armstrong?
No Armstrong.
Is he giving a maintenance alert?
No, Captain. Optimum thrust on all fighters except Armstrong's. Do we launch without him?
Launch.
(comms) This is XO Moore to Damocles Squadron. Launch, launch, launch. (normal) All launched craft on course and running smooth, leaving Pluto orbital path. Armstrong reports stalled.
Stalled? Recall Damocles fighters.
What about Armstrong?
He's our finest pilot, and he just jeopardised the operational efficiency of Earth's front-line defences. Defences that all our lives depend upon. I want him in my office, now.
There we are, that's better.
Panic over?
There was never any panic.
You let your tea go cold.
I was busy.
Panicking?
All right, I'll concede that perhaps I was a little worried, for a short time.
About half an hour.
Half? Really.
Shall I pour you another cup? I've made some more. Doctor, you're not listening, are you?
What? Er, no. I mean, yes. Yes, everything's perfectly
Normal?
Yes.
Flicks switches, beeps.
We were heading for Earth, am I right? Doctor?
Hmm? Oh yes, yes, yes, you're right.
And then?
And then, what?
And then your face fell about a mile, and your tea got cold. And things still aren't right, are they?
No.
There, wasn't difficult, was it? Doctor, you have to tell me. What is it?
I'm sorry, Evelyn, it's, it's just that something
Something?
Something scared me.
Scared?
And I'm not sure why.
What happened? Sit down. I'll pour you that tea. There.
Thank you. We were about to materialise on Earth, then at the last minute I realised we'd slipped into your future, quite a long way. Probably two or three centuries, maybe more.
Well, we've had worse slips than that, haven't we?
Yes. Yes, I suppose we have. Excellent tea. Thank you.
You're very welcome. What frightened you, Doctor?
I'm. Well, there was something very wrong about the readings.
The readings for Earth?

Yes. You see, I know your planet's history so well, it's always like popping in on an old friend for tea. But this time, just for a second, I got this feeling that I'd stumbled in on complete strangers, that something was so terribly wrong that
Go on.

I don't know, Evelyn. I really don't know, and I. But you're right, I panicked. I flipped everything into reverse, we shot backwards in Time and straight back out into deep space. Oh, did I say this tea was excellent?
You did. And now?
And now, I've slowed us down. We're still going back, floating gently back through Time and Space, heading towards Earth's solar system and your century.
Well, that's good then, isn't it?
Yes. It should be.
Should be?
Evelyn.
Yes?
For some reason I don't understand, I'm still afraid.
But
Bell rings.
What was that?
Let's find out. If I can just locate a match for it in the Tardis databank. Let's have a look. Here, something from your past. A sound from Earth that the Tardis dates at around 1950 AD.
Seems like you reversed us too far.
No, we're currently traversing the year 2197 and we're just approaching the outskirts of your solar system.
Then why are we hearing a sound from Earth in the 1950s?
And what exactly is it? If I can just. It's gone. No trace of it.
Well, didn't you, I don't know, tape record it or something?
Yes, something like that, but there's no record of it at all. It's
What?
It's as if we never heard it.
Doctor, we did hear it. Very much so.
I know.
What are you doing now?
Finding some answers.
In the middle of nowhere, on the outskirts of the solar system?
No, not nowhere. There's something out there.
The Tardis materialises.
Armstrong, you're just not making any sense.
I'm sorry.
So you keep saying.
But if you'd heard it, Captain, you'd understand.
There was no bell. No one else heard it, and we've checked everywhere.
I heard it! I heard it and I never want to hear it again. (crying) You don't understand. It wasn't just a sound, it, it felt like
What? Like what?
Like it was, it was. No, I can't. I can't. I don't want to.
XO.
[OC]: Captain?
Get the MO in here. Armstrong's suspended from all duties pending a medical report.
[OC]: Armstrong's ill, Captain?
I don't Know what he is, but he's no use to me.
[OC]: Sectors eleven and twelve are now clear for radiation testing.
It even looks like an aircraft carrier, doesn't it? I remember seeing the Ark Royal

Same principle. Large vessel supporting a squadron of fighter aircraft, except that's the launch pad down there, not a runway. Compartments open up and the Damocles fighters shoot straight out into space. The deadliest fighter craft of their age. The envy of their enemies.
If this is a military vessel, aren't they going to be a bit unhappy about two strangers wandering around on board?
Undoubtedly. But we're not going to be here for long. I just need to take a few readings. Oh.
If you can get that thing to work.
It is working.
What's it telling you?
I'm not sure. Interesting. But I can't hear any bells. Can you?
Doctor.
Hmm?
Hello. Sorry if we're trespassing.
What? Oh. Oh dear.
Keep your hands where I can see them and drop that thing.
Thing? Oh, my tracker. Ah, now the trouble is, if I drop it, it'll break, and I'd really rather
Drop it!
Clatter, fizzle, splutter.
I did warn you.
O'Keefe?
Yes, Captain. He just found then wandering around.
Were they armed?
No, but the male was carrying some sort of device. But O'Keefe made him drop it and er, well.
Well what?
It broke.
Fascinating, Mister Moore.
Sorry.
Do we know how they got on board?
Er
I mean, do we know anything about them apart from what they've dropped on the deck?
Well, they look a bit odd.
Odd? I've got an ace pilot who's hearing bells and crying like a baby, and now I've got odd people. I do hope there isn't a pattern emerging here.
Knock on metal door.
That'll be the prisoners now. Shall I
Yes, XO.
Door slides open.
Send them in.
I'm guessing you're not going to let us sit down.
What on Earth am I supposed to make of you two?
Well, yes, good point.
Let's start with your names.
I'm Evelyn Smythe, and this is the Doctor.
The Doctor. And why are you here, Evelyn Smythe and the Doctor?
Well, it's a bit difficult to explain, to be honest.
Try being a bit more honest, Doctor. Are you good at reading faces, either of you?
Faces?

Well, I'm just interested to know if you think that this is the face of a patient person. Of a person who's not going to suddenly lose her temper and have you shot! Am I giving you some incentive here?
We were looking for a bell.
A bell?
Yes. I Know it doesn't make sense, it's just that we, well, we heard a bell and, oh dear. Doctor?
Oh, carry on. You're doing admirably.
Oh, thanks a lot.
You heard a bell.
Well, yes.
Yes, we did. Ring any bells with you?
Have you ever heard about raiders using bells, XO?
Bells? No, Captain.
No. You see my problem, Doctor.
Er, not quite.

My standing orders are to protect Earth's solar system from alien raiding parties which have, in the last decade, caused unacceptable levels of damage to cargo payloads and loss of life in the outer. Are you getting the picture, Doctor? I've been trained extensively for my job. We're all highly trained military personnel here, ready to engage the enemy.
These alien raiders.
You talk as if you've never heard of them. But you haven't, have you. Have you?

Alien raiders? Oh, yes, I do remember something about them. Privateers from the Endosian Alliance made several incursions into Earth's solar system during the last half of the 22nd century and early 23rd.
Doctor.
The last half of the? You know, I'm not even going to bother continuing this conversation.
Oh well.
I'm not trained to deal with bell-ringing free-loading simpletons dressed like, like I don't know what the hell what.
I quite understand. You've got a job to do. You don't want us getting in the way. Probably best if you just let us go.
Go? Where are you going to go?

Well? It's a good question. If you're expecting to be able to just go, what, you didn't stow away before take-off? You've just recently arrived? Is that what you're expecting me to believe? XO, have we detected any spacecraft?
Nothing, Captain. I checked and
Freeze them. That's what we'll do, freeze them.
What?
They can be someone else's problem when we get back to Earth.
Oh, we'd really rather you didn't do that.
Oh, you'd really rather I didn't? How absolutely fascinating. Well, I'm joking, of course, because it's not fascinating at all. It's just annoying!
Please, don't upset yourself on our account. We really are completely inconsequential.
Well, there we agree, Doctor, because I'll tell you what you are, shall I? Shall 1?
Er, by all means.
An entry in my next comms package to High Command. Unidentified intruders frozen for further interrogation. Thank you, goodbye. Mister Moore?
Captain?
Get them out of my sight.
Captain. Right, you two
Oh, there is just one thing.
Doctor, perhaps we should just
What, let them freeze us? I don't think either of us
Get them out of here, XO!
The bell. You know something about it, don't you. Ah ha. I thought so.
That'll help, being smug. Well done.
Have you heard it?
I don't have time for this.
Well, maybe not you, then. Someone else. Someone else has, haven't they?
One of our pilots, Armstrong.
Yes, thank you, Mister Moore.
Sorry, ma'am.
One of your pilots heard the bell.
Our pilot says he heard a bell.
You don't believe him?
I
You're not sure.
There's something wrong with him.
Armstrong, can we see him?
What?
Talk to him.
No. Why?
We just want to help.
How can you help?
I try my best.
You try
[Tannoy]: Attention, attention. This is an Operations alert. Scramble. Scramble.
XO?
It's not a drill, Captain. Operations Control, this is the XO.
[OC]: Two confirmed raider contacts.
Get these people out of here, Moore.
Ma'am.
But you're not going to freeze us?
Shut up! I don't know! No.
Thank you. And your pilot, Armstrong, can we
Don't push your luck, Doctor. Move it.
O'KEEFE [OC]: Wing Leader to Control. All craft space-borne. We have tactical. Now plotting intercept course.

[OC]: Attack pattern delta delta sierra niner. Your targets read as ion drive spacers. Course coordinates confirm their target is Jupiter Moon or Station. Arm your DX missiles immediately. Acknowledge, Wing Leader.
O'KEEFE [OC]: Wing Leader acknowledging.
What are you looking so pleased about?
We're not frozen, and the crew of this ship are preoccupied. Which means, with any luck, we can get away.
If they haven't already found the Tardis and put a guard on it, or thrown it into space.
What a little ray of sunshine you are, Evelyn.
And what are we going to do about this wretched bell?
Hmm? Well, if we can find the pilot who heard it
This Armstrong chap.
Yes, and ask him a few questions
It's a pretty big ship, Doctor, and we don't know what he looks like.
But we know his name, and they said there was something wrong with him. All we have to do is find the sickbay.
Oh, is that all? After we've got out of here, of course.
Yes. Now, Earth military locks in the late 22nd century. Rather susceptible to high frequency vibrations, as I recall.
I'm not very good at vibrating. Are you?

I used to have a rather handy screwdriver thing that did my vibrating for me. I really must build a new one some day. Still, necessity is the mother of invention, and I do have perfect pitch, you know.
Oh please, you're not going to sing.
Oh, it's much worse than that, Evelyn.
I find that hard to believe. What are you going to do?
What a pity there isn't a blackboard in here.
I tell you what. You just carry on being unfathomable and brilliant, and I'll just sit here and be entertained.

How very obliging of you. No, fingernails down a blackboard would have produced just about the right range of frequencies to give this door lock the jitters. Still, fingernails down a metal wall should be good enough.
Scraping noise.
Oh, Doctor!
Don't just sit there oh doctoring. This is a two man job. I scratch, you bash the door. In fact, kick it.
What if there's someone on the other, oh, all right, all right.
Scraping.
Slightly higher pitch, I think. And kick it harder. Ready?
Ready.
Scrape, thump, creak.
(sotto) Anyone on the other side?
(sotto) Er, no. No one.
(sotto) Thought as much. They're too busy fighting off Endosians to worry about us. Come on.
O'KEEFE [OC]: We've got them on track.
Good work, O'Keefe. Weapons status?
O'KEEFE [OC]: DX missiles armed and ready to deploy.
What's that, XO?
Wing Leader, we show your targets now breaking for cover.
We see it, XO. Now in pursuit.
Watch those ion trails, O'Keefe. They kill.
Acknowledged.
Yeah, they're going for cover behind lo. XO, you'll need to supply our people with accurate tracking data once they've lost visual contact. XO?
Bell rings.
(scared) No. No. No, please, no. I don't, I don't want
XO! What's the matter?
Nothing. Sorry, Captain, nothing.
Doctor Leopard? Don't be ridiculous, Doctor.
It's true. The Endosian privateers had a penchant for the melodramatic. Their leaders always chose names that
That's not melodramatic. It's just a bit camp, if you ask me.
Ah, you wouldn't dare say that if you met him. Eight feet tall, rippling mauve muscles and three heads. Well, I think it was three.
Bless you, Doctor. The sillier your stories get, the more serious I know the situation is.
Ah, I was right. They're still using the red cross symbol. Now all we have to do is follow
these arrows, and we should find the sickbay and our Mister Armstrong.
You're still worried, aren't you?
About the bell?
About what you saw. What had happened to Earth.
Yes. But I'm on the trail of something now. We'll solve it, don't you worry.
What exactly did you see?
You know those dreams, when you go back home, your childhood home, and everything's changed. You know it should be familiar, but not one thing is as you remember it, as it should be.
No, I've never had a dream like that.
Maybe humans don't have them. Maybe it's only Time Lords. Or just me.
Door slides open.
Quick, get back.
Running boots.
They were in a hurry.
Luckily for us. The battle alert is still on, then. Come on.
O'KEEFE [OC]: Tracking data negative. Visual contact lost.
What? XO, what's happening with that tracking? XO?
I, I (bell) No. No, please, no.
O'KEEFE [OC]: Visual contact dead ahead! Break, break, break!
You idiot, Moore.
O'Keefe screams.
Ah, this is it. Sickbay.
We can't just burst in there. What if there's more than one patient?
We could try asking, anyone heard any bells?
Best to be direct, I suppose.
Door slides open.
No, I can't.
Armstrong?
What? Yes.
I don't believe it. Talk about luck.
Who are you?
Oh, it may be luck, but I've got a feeling it's all bad.
Doctor, he's
Where are you going, Mister Armstrong?
I must. I must. No, please.
You must what, go somewhere? Where? Anything to do with a bell?
You can hear it?
No.
But you can.
Why can no one else hear it? What's the matter with me?
I don't know, but we're here to help you. Where are you going?
I must, I must.
We're following?
We're following.
No contact. None at all.
[OC]: Raiders now out of range. Damocles fighter transponder signals negative.
Moore! XO! What the hell did you think you were? We have lost the entire squadron and it's your fault.
The squadron? But, what? I can't. No.
Moore? Moore, what's the matter with you?
Can't you hear it?
What?
The bell.
Doctor, he's led us straight to the Tardis.
I must
Coincidence, or? Evelyn, keep him here, will you?
He seems to have stopped anyway. Why? What are you going to do?
We can't hear the bell, but he can. Maybe the Tardis can too, since he's standing right next to it. And maybe I can get some answers this time. Won't be a minute.
Armstrong? Armstrong? Can you hear me?
What? Who are you? Is it you?
Is what me?
Ringing the bell.
No. Armstrong, listen to me. Why have you brought us down here, to this storage bay? Is it the Tardis, this blue box you
I must go. I must. I can't help.
Not the Tardis, then.
No choice. I must.
That door? What's behind that door, Armstrong?
Nowhere.
Console beeps. Bell rings.
A door? I don't remember that being there before. No, that doesn't make sense. What? Well, that can't be right.
But why should you want to go nowhere?
No.
It's all right, Armstrong. You don't have to if you don't want to. You can stay here with me.
I don't want to, don't you understand? I don't. It wants me.
It? What do you mean?
And I have to go.
Door slides open.
(distant) Evelyn! Stop him! Don't let him go through that door!
Armstrong! No!
Screams. It fades and the door closes.
Armstrong!
Gone. He's gone. What was that terrible noise?
I don't know. Did you see through there?
Well, not really. It was just nothing. Nowhere.
Nowhere? What do you mean?
It's what that poor man said. I asked him what was behind the door. He said, nowhere. But that's impossible.
Impossible, yes. But that's just the third impossible thing about that door.
Third?
Well, look at it. See the view ports either side?
Oh, my goodness. It leads straight out into space.
No airlock, just a simple door in the hull of this ship.
Shouldn't we have been, well, blown out into the vacuum?
Precisely. But we weren't.
You said there were three impossible things.
Yes. I scanned for the bell.
Could you hear it again, in the Tardis?
Yes. But I didn't get a chance to find out much about it.
Why not?
I was distracted.
By what?
According to the Tardis, that door is over fifty billion years old.
(That makes it from the far, far distant future, given that the universe is currently dated at 13.82 billion, and the Earth at 4.54 billion.)

EVELYN: Go on.
DOCTOR: I don't know, Evelyn. I really don't know, and I. But you're right, I panicked. I flipped everything into reverse, we shot backwards in Time and straight back out into deep space. Oh, did I say this tea was excellent?
EVELYN: You did. And now?
DOCTOR: And now, I've slowed us down. We're still going back, floating gently back through Time and Space, heading towards Earth's solar system and your century.
EVELYN: Well, that's good then, isn't it?
DOCTOR: Yes. It should be.
EVELYN: Should be?

EVELYN: Yes?

EVELYN: What was that?

DOCTOR: Yes, something like that, but there's no record of it at all. It's
EVELYN: What?
DOCTOR: It's as if we never heard it.
EVELYN: Doctor, we did hear it. Very much so.
DOCTOR: I know.
EVELYN: What are you doing now?
DOCTOR: Finding some answers.
EVELYN: In the middle of nowhere, on the outskirts of the solar system?
DOCTOR: No, not nowhere. There's something out there.

ARMSTRONG: I'm sorry.
OSWIN: So you keep saying.

OSWIN: I don't Know what he is, but he's no use to me.

EVELYN: If you can get that thing to work.
DOCTOR: It is working.
EVELYN: What's it telling you?
DOCTOR: I'm not sure. Interesting. But I can't hear any bells. Can you?
EVELYN: Doctor.
DOCTOR: Hmm?
EVELYN: Hello. Sorry if we're trespassing.
DOCTOR: What? Oh. Oh dear.
O'KEEFE: Keep your hands where I can see them and drop that thing.
DOCTOR: Thing? Oh, my tracker. Ah, now the trouble is, if I drop it, it'll break, and I'd really rather
O'KEEFE: Drop it!
DOCTOR: I did warn you.
OSWIN: O'Keefe?
MOORE: Yes, Captain. He just found then wandering around.
OSWIN: Were they armed?
MOORE: No, but the male was carrying some sort of device. But O'Keefe made him drop it and er, well.
OSWIN: Well what?
MOORE: It broke.
OSWIN: Fascinating, Mister Moore.
MOORE: Sorry.
OSWIN: Do we know how they got on board?
MOORE: Er
OSWIN: I mean, do we know anything about them apart from what they've dropped on the deck?
MOORE: Well, they look a bit odd.
OSWIN: Odd? I've got an ace pilot who's hearing bells and crying like a baby, and now I've got odd people. I do hope there isn't a pattern emerging here.
MOORE: That'll be the prisoners now. Shall I
OSWIN: Yes, XO.
MOORE: Send them in.
DOCTOR: I'm guessing you're not going to let us sit down.
OSWIN: What on Earth am I supposed to make of you two?
DOCTOR: Well, yes, good point.
OSWIN: Let's start with your names.
EVELYN: I'm Evelyn Smythe, and this is the Doctor.
OSWIN: The Doctor. And why are you here, Evelyn Smythe and the Doctor?
DOCTOR: Well, it's a bit difficult to explain, to be honest.
OSWIN: Try being a bit more honest, Doctor. Are you good at reading faces, either of you?
EVELYN: Faces?
OSWIN: Well, I'm just interested to know if you think that this is the face of a patient person. Of a person who's not going to suddenly lose her temper and have you shot! Am I giving you some incentive here?
EVELYN: We were looking for a bell.
MOORE: A bell?
EVELYN: Yes. I Know it doesn't make sense, it's just that we, well, we heard a bell and, oh dear. Doctor?
DOCTOR: Oh, carry on. You're doing admirably.
EVELYN: Oh, thanks a lot.
OSWIN: You heard a bell.
EVELYN: Well, yes.
DOCTOR: Yes, we did. Ring any bells with you?
OSWIN: Have you ever heard about raiders using bells, XO?
MOORE: Bells? No, Captain.
OSWIN: No. You see my problem, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Er, not quite.
OSWIN: My standing orders are to protect Earth's solar system from alien raiding parties which have, in the last decade, caused unacceptable levels of damage to cargo payloads and loss of life in the outer. Are you getting the picture, Doctor? I've been trained extensively for my job. We're all highly trained military personnel here, ready to engage the enemy.
EVELYN: These alien raiders.
OSWIN: You talk as if you've never heard of them. But you haven't, have you. Have you?
DOCTOR: Alien raiders? Oh, yes, I do remember something about them. Privateers from the Endosian Alliance made several incursions into Earth's solar system during the last half of the 22nd century and early 23rd.
EVELYN: Doctor.
OSWIN: The last half of the? You know, I'm not even going to bother continuing this conversation.
DOCTOR: Oh well.
OSWIN: I'm not trained to deal with bell-ringing free-loading simpletons dressed like, like I don't know what the hell what.
DOCTOR: I quite understand. You've got a job to do. You don't want us getting in the way. Probably best if you just let us go.
MOORE: Go? Where are you going to go?
OSWIN: Well? It's a good question. If you're expecting to be able to just go, what, you didn't stow away before take-off? You've just recently arrived? Is that what you're expecting me to believe? XO, have we detected any spacecraft?
MOORE: Nothing, Captain. I checked and
OSWIN: Freeze them. That's what we'll do, freeze them.
DOCTOR: What?
OSWIN: They can be someone else's problem when we get back to Earth.
DOCTOR: Oh, we'd really rather you didn't do that.
OSWIN: Oh, you'd really rather I didn't? How absolutely fascinating. Well, I'm joking, of course, because it's not fascinating at all. It's just annoying!
DOCTOR: Please, don't upset yourself on our account. We really are completely inconsequential.
OSWIN: Well, there we agree, Doctor, because I'll tell you what you are, shall I? Shall 1?
DOCTOR: Er, by all means.
OSWIN: An entry in my next comms package to High Command. Unidentified intruders frozen for further interrogation. Thank you, goodbye. Mister Moore?
MOORE: Captain?
OSWIN: Get them out of my sight.
MOORE: Captain. Right, you two
DOCTOR: Oh, there is just one thing.
EVELYN: Doctor, perhaps we should just
DOCTOR: What, let them freeze us? I don't think either of us
OSWIN: Get them out of here, XO!
DOCTOR: The bell. You know something about it, don't you. Ah ha. I thought so.
EVELYN: That'll help, being smug. Well done.
DOCTOR: Have you heard it?
OSWIN: I don't have time for this.
DOCTOR: Well, maybe not you, then. Someone else. Someone else has, haven't they?
MOORE: One of our pilots, Armstrong.
OSWIN: Yes, thank you, Mister Moore.
MOORE: Sorry, ma'am.
EVELYN: One of your pilots heard the bell.
OSWIN: Our pilot says he heard a bell.
DOCTOR: You don't believe him?
OSWIN: I
DOCTOR: You're not sure.
OSWIN: There's something wrong with him.
DOCTOR: Armstrong, can we see him?
OSWIN: What?
DOCTOR: Talk to him.
OSWIN: No. Why?
EVELYN: We just want to help.
OSWIN: How can you help?
DOCTOR: I try my best.
OSWIN: You try
OPERATIONS: [Tannoy]: Attention, attention. This is an Operations alert. Scramble. Scramble.
OSWIN: XO?
MOORE: It's not a drill, Captain. Operations Control, this is the XO.
OPERATIONS: [OC]: Two confirmed raider contacts.
OSWIN: Get these people out of here, Moore.
MOORE: Ma'am.
EVELYN: But you're not going to freeze us?
OSWIN: Shut up! I don't know! No.
DOCTOR: Thank you. And your pilot, Armstrong, can we
MOORE: Don't push your luck, Doctor. Move it.
MOORE: O'KEEFE [OC]: Wing Leader to Control. All craft space-borne. We have tactical. Now plotting intercept course.
OPERATIONS: [OC]: Attack pattern delta delta sierra niner. Your targets read as ion drive spacers. Course coordinates confirm their target is Jupiter Moon or Station. Arm your DX missiles immediately. Acknowledge, Wing Leader.
OPERATIONS: O'KEEFE [OC]: Wing Leader acknowledging.
EVELYN: What are you looking so pleased about?
DOCTOR: We're not frozen, and the crew of this ship are preoccupied. Which means, with any luck, we can get away.
EVELYN: If they haven't already found the Tardis and put a guard on it, or thrown it into space.
DOCTOR: What a little ray of sunshine you are, Evelyn.
EVELYN: And what are we going to do about this wretched bell?
DOCTOR: Hmm? Well, if we can find the pilot who heard it
EVELYN: This Armstrong chap.
DOCTOR: Yes, and ask him a few questions
EVELYN: It's a pretty big ship, Doctor, and we don't know what he looks like.
DOCTOR: But we know his name, and they said there was something wrong with him. All we have to do is find the sickbay.
EVELYN: Oh, is that all? After we've got out of here, of course.
DOCTOR: Yes. Now, Earth military locks in the late 22nd century. Rather susceptible to high frequency vibrations, as I recall.
EVELYN: I'm not very good at vibrating. Are you?
DOCTOR: I used to have a rather handy screwdriver thing that did my vibrating for me. I really must build a new one some day. Still, necessity is the mother of invention, and I do have perfect pitch, you know.
EVELYN: Oh please, you're not going to sing.
DOCTOR: Oh, it's much worse than that, Evelyn.
EVELYN: I find that hard to believe. What are you going to do?
DOCTOR: What a pity there isn't a blackboard in here.
EVELYN: I tell you what. You just carry on being unfathomable and brilliant, and I'll just sit here and be entertained.
DOCTOR: How very obliging of you. No, fingernails down a blackboard would have produced just about the right range of frequencies to give this door lock the jitters. Still, fingernails down a metal wall should be good enough.
EVELYN: Oh, Doctor!
DOCTOR: Don't just sit there oh doctoring. This is a two man job. I scratch, you bash the door. In fact, kick it.
EVELYN: What if there's someone on the other, oh, all right, all right.
DOCTOR: Slightly higher pitch, I think. And kick it harder. Ready?
EVELYN: Ready.
DOCTOR: (sotto) Anyone on the other side?
EVELYN: (sotto) Er, no. No one.
DOCTOR: (sotto) Thought as much. They're too busy fighting off Endosians to worry about us. Come on.
DOCTOR: O'KEEFE [OC]: We've got them on track.
OSWIN: Good work, O'Keefe. Weapons status?
OSWIN: O'KEEFE [OC]: DX missiles armed and ready to deploy.
OSWIN: What's that, XO?
MOORE: Wing Leader, we show your targets now breaking for cover.
O'KEEFE: We see it, XO. Now in pursuit.
OSWIN: Watch those ion trails, O'Keefe. They kill.
O'KEEFE: Acknowledged.
OSWIN: Yeah, they're going for cover behind lo. XO, you'll need to supply our people with accurate tracking data once they've lost visual contact. XO?
MOORE: (scared) No. No. No, please, no. I don't, I don't want
OSWIN: XO! What's the matter?
MOORE: Nothing. Sorry, Captain, nothing.
EVELYN: Doctor Leopard? Don't be ridiculous, Doctor.
DOCTOR: It's true. The Endosian privateers had a penchant for the melodramatic. Their leaders always chose names that
EVELYN: That's not melodramatic. It's just a bit camp, if you ask me.
DOCTOR: Ah, you wouldn't dare say that if you met him. Eight feet tall, rippling mauve muscles and three heads. Well, I think it was three.
EVELYN: Bless you, Doctor. The sillier your stories get, the more serious I know the situation is.
DOCTOR: Ah, I was right. They're still using the red cross symbol. Now all we have to do is follow
DOCTOR: these arrows, and we should find the sickbay and our Mister Armstrong.
EVELYN: You're still worried, aren't you?
DOCTOR: About the bell?
EVELYN: About what you saw. What had happened to Earth.
DOCTOR: Yes. But I'm on the trail of something now. We'll solve it, don't you worry.
EVELYN: What exactly did you see?
DOCTOR: You know those dreams, when you go back home, your childhood home, and everything's changed. You know it should be familiar, but not one thing is as you remember it, as it should be.
EVELYN: No, I've never had a dream like that.
DOCTOR: Maybe humans don't have them. Maybe it's only Time Lords. Or just me.
DOCTOR: Quick, get back.
EVELYN: They were in a hurry.
DOCTOR: Luckily for us. The battle alert is still on, then. Come on.
DOCTOR: O'KEEFE [OC]: Tracking data negative. Visual contact lost.
OSWIN: What? XO, what's happening with that tracking? XO?
MOORE: I, I (bell) No. No, please, no.
MOORE: O'KEEFE [OC]: Visual contact dead ahead! Break, break, break!
OSWIN: You idiot, Moore.
DOCTOR: Ah, this is it. Sickbay.
EVELYN: We can't just burst in there. What if there's more than one patient?
DOCTOR: We could try asking, anyone heard any bells?
EVELYN: Best to be direct, I suppose.
ARMSTRONG: No, I can't.
DOCTOR: Armstrong?
ARMSTRONG: What? Yes.
EVELYN: I don't believe it. Talk about luck.
ARMSTRONG: Who are you?
DOCTOR: Oh, it may be luck, but I've got a feeling it's all bad.
EVELYN: Doctor, he's
DOCTOR: Where are you going, Mister Armstrong?
ARMSTRONG: I must. I must. No, please.
DOCTOR: You must what, go somewhere? Where? Anything to do with a bell?
ARMSTRONG: You can hear it?
DOCTOR: No.
EVELYN: But you can.
ARMSTRONG: Why can no one else hear it? What's the matter with me?
DOCTOR: I don't know, but we're here to help you. Where are you going?
ARMSTRONG: I must, I must.
EVELYN: We're following?
DOCTOR: We're following.
OSWIN: No contact. None at all.
OPERATIONS: [OC]: Raiders now out of range. Damocles fighter transponder signals negative.
OSWIN: Moore! XO! What the hell did you think you were? We have lost the entire squadron and it's your fault.
MOORE: The squadron? But, what? I can't. No.
OSWIN: Moore? Moore, what's the matter with you?
MOORE: Can't you hear it?
OSWIN: What?
MOORE: The bell.
EVELYN: Doctor, he's led us straight to the Tardis.
ARMSTRONG: I must
DOCTOR: Coincidence, or? Evelyn, keep him here, will you?
EVELYN: He seems to have stopped anyway. Why? What are you going to do?
DOCTOR: We can't hear the bell, but he can. Maybe the Tardis can too, since he's standing right next to it. And maybe I can get some answers this time. Won't be a minute.
EVELYN: Armstrong? Armstrong? Can you hear me?
ARMSTRONG: What? Who are you? Is it you?
EVELYN: Is what me?
ARMSTRONG: Ringing the bell.
EVELYN: No. Armstrong, listen to me. Why have you brought us down here, to this storage bay? Is it the Tardis, this blue box you
ARMSTRONG: I must go. I must. I can't help.
EVELYN: Not the Tardis, then.
ARMSTRONG: No choice. I must.
EVELYN: That door? What's behind that door, Armstrong?
ARMSTRONG: Nowhere.
DOCTOR: A door? I don't remember that being there before. No, that doesn't make sense. What? Well, that can't be right.
EVELYN: But why should you want to go nowhere?
ARMSTRONG: No.
EVELYN: It's all right, Armstrong. You don't have to if you don't want to. You can stay here with me.
ARMSTRONG: I don't want to, don't you understand? I don't. It wants me.
EVELYN: It? What do you mean?
ARMSTRONG: And I have to go.
DOCTOR: (distant) Evelyn! Stop him! Don't let him go through that door!
EVELYN: Armstrong! No!
DOCTOR: Armstrong!
EVELYN: Gone. He's gone. What was that terrible noise?
DOCTOR: I don't know. Did you see through there?
EVELYN: Well, not really. It was just nothing. Nowhere.
DOCTOR: Nowhere? What do you mean?
EVELYN: It's what that poor man said. I asked him what was behind the door. He said, nowhere. But that's impossible.
DOCTOR: Impossible, yes. But that's just the third impossible thing about that door.
EVELYN: Third?
DOCTOR: Well, look at it. See the view ports either side?
EVELYN: Oh, my goodness. It leads straight out into space.
DOCTOR: No airlock, just a simple door in the hull of this ship.
EVELYN: Shouldn't we have been, well, blown out into the vacuum?
DOCTOR: Precisely. But we weren't.
EVELYN: You said there were three impossible things.
DOCTOR: Yes. I scanned for the bell.
EVELYN: Could you hear it again, in the Tardis?
DOCTOR: Yes. But I didn't get a chance to find out much about it.
EVELYN: Why not?
DOCTOR: I was distracted.
EVELYN: By what?
DOCTOR: According to the Tardis, that door is over fifty billion years old.
DOCTOR: (That makes it from the far, far distant future, given that the universe is currently dated at 13.82 billion, and the Earth at 4.54 billion.)

elements.text: [Part Two]
Still no transponder signals from our people?
[OC]: Still negative.
What about the raiders?
[OC]: No signal detected.
XO! Moore, you've got to tell me. What the hell's the matter with you? Don't you understand? We've lost the Damocles fighters because of you. There is no bell. Get a grip of yourself!
(crying) I heard it.
But no one else here did.
Armstrong heard it, and now I can.
For God's sake, Moore, this doesn't make any sense. Oswin to sickbay.
[OC]: Er sickbay.
I want to speak to Armstrong. Sickbay?
[OC]: Oh, er, yeah, he's er. (sotto) Where is he? What? (normal) He doesn't appear to be here, Captain.
What? What'd you mean?
[OC]: Well, we thought he, I dunno, he must have slipped out, somehow.
Slipped? You don't just let them. (sighs) Never mind. Master at Arms, this is the Captain. MASTER AT ARMS [OC]: Captain.
Pilot Armstrong's gone walkabout. He's not right in the head. Find him.
It wanted him to go through this door?
Yes. Whatever it is.
And there was nothing in there? A door that shouldn't be here, and it leads to nowhere. But we heard something.
Something horrible.
But we heard it. Like the bell. Maybe if I

Shh. Listening. Listening at the door to nowhere.
Anything?
Shh.
Distant train whistle.
Did you hear that?
No. What?
Come and listen.
Ops? What the hell's happening now?
[OC]: Damocles transponder codes detected.
What?
(sotto) Thank God, thank God.
How many? Look, patch me through. O'Keefe? O'Keefe, are you reading me? (static) O'Keefe!
O'KEEFE [OC]: Captain, can you hear me?
O'Keefe, what happened? Are you all right?
O'KEEFE [OC]: Got caught in an ion trail. We, we lost Hayward. (static)
O'Keefe! O'Keefe, are you reading me?
O'KEEFE [OC]: Yeah, yeah. Systems are pretty shook up. Rest of us okay, but our instrumentation was knocked out. It's taken us this long to reboot.
What about the raiders?
O'KEEFE [OC]: They got away. What happened, Captain? When we lost visual we didn't get any tracking data from you.
We had er problems at this end, O'Keefe.
O'KEEFE [OC]: Problems?
All Damocles fighters are recalled to Valiant, O'Keefe.
O'KEEFE [OC]: Understood. ETA 0450.
Very well.
It's a steam train.
What is?
Don't you recognise the sound?
What sound?
What, you can't hear it?
No.
But it (bell rings) The signal bell. It's arriving at the station. (train whistle)
Doctor, you're scaring me.
Muffled voice.
Tickets please. Didn't you hear that?
What? No, I can't. Doctor, are you sure you're all right?
No, I'm not sure. There are people talking. Something, something familiar.
Doctor, are you certain you're hearing this? It's not, I don't know, some kind of telepathy or something like that?
No, it's coming from behind that door. But why can't you hear it?
I don't know. It's like that, like Armstrong. He could hear the bell, but we couldn't.
But I'm not being drawn to the door, and it isn't opening.
Thank goodness for that. (train bell) You can hear something else, can't you?
Train whistle.
I think the sequence is repeating. Yes, it's a sequence of sounds.
You said it was a steam train. It must be coming from the past, like the bell.
But how? And why?
They've what? How?
No idea, ma'am. We just found the door open.
Why wasn't there a guard on the door?
All personnel were called to secure stations.
Right, fine. What about Armstrong?
Still no sign, but we've got the prisoners on the security screen.
Patch it through to me. That's one of our storage bays, isn't it? What are they doing down there?
Er, maybe they're. I've no idea, ma'am.
And what's that, a storage crate?
MASTER AT ARMS [OC]: Er, no
No idea? You surprise me. Well, whatever it is, they've just gone inside it. Get a team down there now. I'll meet you there. XO, how are you feeling?
Er, better. I think.
Good. You're with me.
Is the Tardis picking up that train sound?
Er, yes. Now, can you hear that?
Yes, yes I can. And that's what you could hear at the door?
Yes. It sounds like a
Don't tell me you're a train spotter.
When you've lived as long as I have, you'll try out all sorts of hobbies. Well, for a time, at least.
All right, then. Impress me with your train spotting.
I'm a bit rusty, but it's a small locomotive. Probably something used on one of the old branch lines.
Presumably from the 1950s, like the bell.
It narrows it down, that's for sure.
So, before Doctor Beeching's closures.
Oh, Doctor Beeching's axe. Who's the anorak now?
Elementary social history.
It all helps. Of course! The bell. It's a station signal bell. Come on, old girl. She's done it.
Turret class locomotive withdrawn from Northern and Western line 1953.
And the Tardis has narrowed the origin of the sound down to the 7th of September in the year 1952.
How many Turret class locomotives still in service in 1952?
Let's find out. (keyboard sounds) One. Just one.
Stapley Moor Riverside line. Turret class locomotive Ivy Lee.
That's her. Ivy Lee. That's our girl.
Then let's find her.
One last thing before we leave. I want to get a fragment of that fifty billion year old door out there.
I can't work out what it's doing out here. It's obviously not really part of this ship, yet it looks exactly like all the other doors.
Precisely. Now, if I can just chip a bit off this. There.
Whatever you're going to do, do it quickly.
Before you get caught?
Ah. Hello. Really no need for guns, honestly.
In my line of work there's always a need for guns.
Interesting philosophy.
Master at Arms, shoot them if they move.
Yes, Captain.
What are you doing to that door?
Were you looking for your friend Armstrong or us?
Both. Do you know where Armstrong is?
Do you remember ever seeing this door before?
Try answering questions, Doctor. We're in a combat situation and you haven't been entered into my log yet. That means you don't exist. Be careful, or I'll keep it that way permanently.
Wait a minute.
XO.
This door. Look.
XO, I'm looking. It's just a, what the hell?
Doesn't make sense, does it?
And it makes even less sense when it opens.
It's not an airlock, just an ordinary door.
You saw it open?
No, but my friend did.
Doctor, we shouldn't be letting
They've got guns. I don't think we have a choice.
Very wise, Doctor. Well, Evelyn? What happened when it opened?
Armstrong, he
Armstrong was here?
Yes. He, he went through.
Through? By my reckoning that door would open directly into space. I've no idea how it got here, but if it were to open then this whole section would be depressurised.
Confusing, isn't it?
You said he went through. Through where?
He could hear the bell.
The bell?
XO, I think perhaps you
You've heard it, haven't you?
No one's
Not you. I mean you, Mister Moore.
When did you hear it?
Master at Arms, escort these prisoners to the detention
If you stand close to it, you may hear something else, Mister Moore.
No!
All right, that's enough.
You heard the bell, didn't you?
Doctor, I advise you
You heard it, and I'll wager that just as you were hearing it, Armstrong was down here walking
Doctor!
He said he could hear the bell. That something wanted him to go through the doorway. That he didn't want to go, but he had no choice.
And he went through. How?
The door opened, and he went through.
That's impossible.
Then where is he?
This is a big ship, Doctor. He's probably
What was behind the door?
XO, I think you're needed in Operations
What was behind the door! Tell me!
Nothing.
What'd you mean, nothing?
Nothing. Nowhere. Just, just a terrible sound.
Train whistle.
(afraid) Please, please no.
What is it, Doctor? You've heard it again, haven't you?
And you?
Nothing.
What the hell are you talking about?
(afraid) Please, please, no.
XO, get a grip of yourself.
You can hear it, can't you?
No.
I think you can.
No. Please.
Right, that's it. Enough. If you don't move, Doctor, I'll shoot you myself.
Wouldn't you rather find out the truth?
Oh, and what is the truth?
I've no idea! That's the trouble. But something
Train whistle.
Well, speak up, Doctor, since you're so fond of talking.
It's all right, Doctor.
No, it isn't, Evelyn. That's the trouble. Nothing feels right at all. Oh no.
What?
You heard it too.
Yes. The bell. Evelyn? Captain? Master at Arms? None of you, except Mister Moore and me.
Doctor, this is my last warning.
Scraping sound.
Doctor, the door!
What the hell? XO, Moore, what are you doing?
I have to. I must. Please, I must.
Stop him. Hold on to him, quickly.
XO, stop!
I must.
Doctor, look! Through the doorway, there's something. I can't quite. Something.
It's very far away. I don't know what.
Help me with him. I can't hold him. Moore!
Everyone, hold on to Moore!
I must!
Moore screams. The door closes.
He just, he just, I don't believe it. Where did he go?
Nowhere.
Who the hell are you people? And what's that crate thing you came out of?
You can't really believe that we're responsible for any of this.
What exactly do you know about that door?
We don't know anything about it. That's the trouble.
Then why are you here? Why are you on my ship?
It's difficult to explain.
No. No, not good enough. Is it alien? Is it a threat? What? What is it? Give me something I can deal with.
Or you'll shoot us? Are you really that out of control, Captain?
All right, Doctor. All right. Take them to my office. Have this section sealed off and guards posted at the intersections.
Right away, ma'am.
This is the Captain to Operations Control. Instigate condition of maximum security alert. This ship, this ship is under attack from unknown alien technology.
I hardly think that's
Full security protocols to be observed at all times. We, we may have been infiltrated.
[OC]: Operations Control to Wing Leader. All Damocles fighters are cleared to land.
Acknowledged, Valiant. This is Wing Leader to squadron. We are clear to land. Park, ride and stand down, ladies.
[OC]: That's a negative, Wing Leader. Your orders are to land and remain at battle readiness.
What's occurring, Operations?
[OC]: Security lock-down. Intruder alert. Security condition one. We may be under attack.
Under attack?
Sit, both of you.
Thank you.
You can leave us, Master at Arms.
Ma'am.
Door slides shut.
That door, did you put it there?
You don't really think that, do you?
What I think is that it's a danger to my crew.
I agree.
It's more than that.
Evelyn.
What?
You have to tell her.
What, exactly? I've no proof of anything. Just feelings.
Feelings?
And my feelings are personal.
I've lost two crew members to that thing, that doorway. Is it alien?
I honestly don't know.
It must be. Are you alien?
No.
What about you, Doctor?
Oh, you think I'm an Endosian privateer, do you, here to raid your storage bay by means of, oh, I don't Know, some sort of dimensional gateway?
Is that what it is? A dimensional
I've no idea. It was just a figure of speech.
Figure? Are you taking the
We've got to tell her the truth.
The truth?
I don't know what the truth is, Evelyn.
We travel in Time and Space. That blue crate you saw, it's our ship.
Oh, really.
Evelyn, this isn't helping.
The Doctor felt that something had gone wrong on Earth.
What do you mean, gone wrong?
Evelyn.
We don't know. It was just, well, just
Oh, don't tell me. Just a feeling.
Yes. And a very powerful one. And I agree, not very helpful.

OSWIN: Clear the crates out, all of them, including that blue thing the intruders came out of. Do it now, and weld the bulkheads shut. Now, before it happens again.
OSWIN: MASTER AT ARMS [OC]: Understood, Captain.
OSWIN: Fighter carrier Valiant, comms package alpha seven zero five, transmitting at ship time 1538 hours, January 16th 2197. Priority One emergency authorisation, Oswin Tanya commanding. Two zero eight zero one seven eight four H W G.
OSWIN: [OC]: Unknown alien force has breached ship's hull and is abducting crew members. All efforts to prevent this or identify the threat have failed. Frequency and severity of attacks increasing. Intruders held in cryogenic suspension for questioning. Alien craft held for analysis. Request investigation team and full military taskforce as soon as possible. Assessment of danger to this command and Earth security extreme. Priority One. Confirming Priority One.
DOCTOR: How long until your taskforce gets here?
OSWIN: Two months.
EVELYN: Two months? But that's not going to be soon enough.
DOCTOR: Assuming they'll be able to do anything when they get here. Captain, you must let us go back.
OSWIN: My hands are tied, Doctor. Something is attacking us, attacking the human race, perhaps even Earth itself.
DOCTOR: You may well be right. All the more reason why
OSWIN: I've no way of verifying anything you've said. For what it's worth, I
EVELYN: You trust us?
OSWIN: I don't think you're responsible for what's happening.
EVELYN: Then let us go.
OSWIN: But that's just a gut feeling. I don't have the authority to make decisions of this scale.
DOCTOR: Tanya, this isn't the time for chains of command and military protocol. There's no telling who will hear the bell next. It may be you, may be the whole crew of your ship. It may be
OSWIN: You? But you've already heard it, haven't you, and you weren't pulled through the door. Why is that, Doctor?
DOCTOR: I don't know.
OSWIN: You see? Too many questions. I can't risk letting you go. You'll be frozen
EVELYN: Why don't you freeze everyone? At least that would stop them walking through the door.
OSWIN: That may yet be an option. I'm sorry, but
COMPUTER: [OC]: Door opening. Door opening.
EVELYN: Doctor, I can't bear this.
OSWIN: I've work to do. You, Crewman First Class Lawford, isn't it?
LAWFORD: Yes, ma'am.
OSWIN: Draw your weapon and escort these two to sickbay. The medical staff have been alerted. They know what to do. Understood?
LAWFORD: Yes, Captain.
OSWIN: Goodbye, Evelyn, Doctor.
EVELYN: Good luck.
OSWIN: And to you. (leaves)
DOCTOR: Well, Mister Lawford. Crewman First Class. You must be very proud.
LAWFORD: Move it.
O'KEEFE: Valiant Operations Control, this is Damocles Wing Leader. First sweep of exclusion zone complete. No sign of alien incursion, no sign of hull breach in storage bay seven.
OPERATIONS: [OC]: Acknowledged, Wing Leader. Priority One alert has been despatched to Earth High Command. Continue sweep until further notice. Acknowledge.
O'KEEFE: l, I
OPERATIONS: [OC]: Acknowledge, Wing Leader. Wing Leader?
O'KEEFE: I must, I must
OPERATIONS: [OC]: Wing Leader? Wing Leader, come in.
COMPUTER: [OC]: Door opening. Door opening.
DOCTOR: It's this way, isn't it, Crewman?
EVELYN: Are you all right?
DOCTOR: Oh no.
LAWFORD: I must, I must
EVELYN: You can hear the bell, can't you?
DOCTOR: The effect is spreading somehow. Are you all right? You can't hear it?
EVELYN: I can't hear it.
DOCTOR: Good. Let's get to the Tardis.
EVELYN: Doctor, we can't just leave him.
DOCTOR: Him. and all the others. We've got to find the root of the problem, Evelyn. If we stay here, we're just patching up a crumbling dam, Come on!
O'KEEFE: I must, I must. Please, I must, I must.
OPERATIONS: [OC]: Wing Leader. Wing Leader, adjust your course and speed immediately. You're heading for imminent impact on Valiant hull. Cut engines!
O'KEEFE: I must
OPERATIONS: [OC]: Cut engines now, O'Keefe! O'Keefe, you're heading for the outer hull section of storage bay seven. Cut engines!
O'KEEFE: I must
OPERATIONS: [OC]: Alter course, for God's sake!
DOCTOR: Captain!
OSWIN: What the hell are you two doing here?
EVELYN: Captain, what happened?
OSWIN: It was O'Keefe.
EVELYN: What was?
DOCTOR: One of the pilots? One of the Damocles pilots?
OSWIN: We saw it all on the security screen. Look.
EVELYN: I don't believe it.
OSWIN: Just crashed his fighter straight into the hull. Shattered it. The door was open. The whole thing, the whole fighter, just sucked right in.
DOCTOR: And nothing left of that section but the door, just standing there, in the middle of space. Open space. The wall, the floor, blown away.
EVELYN: Doctor, look! They managed to save the Tardis!
OSWIN: Oh yes, we've got your precious ship for you. Never mind the twenty crewmen we lost before we sealed the bulkhead.
DOCTOR: Tanya, you must let us go now. We can put this right, I know we can.
OSWIN: How?
DOCTOR: I
OSWIN: You don't know, do you. Why the hell should I trust you? You just want to save your own skins.
MASTER AT ARMS: Captain, the security screen. That door's opening again.
OSWIN: At least no one can get to it now.
DOCTOR: I wouldn't bet on it.
EVELYN: Doctor. Doctor! I, I
DOCTOR: Evelyn, what is it?
EVELYN: I, I can hear the bell.

elements.text: [Part Three]
Right, you're coming with me.
No, I must, I, I must
What are you trying to do, Doctor?
I'm taking her into the Tardis and you're not going to stop me, Tanya.
Master at Arms.
Captain, security report over thirty people on their way here. All of them under the influence of that thing.
They'll never get through that bulkhead now.
I think they'll find a way. I think they'll tear themselves and the bulkhead apart trying to get to that door.
I must
And I'm not waiting around to see my friend
Shoot him if he makes another move, Master at Arms.
Aye, Captain.
Then shoot me! I'd rather die than stay here and watch your entire crew claw their way into nowhere.
You don't know that's going to happen. According to you, you're just as much in the dark as we are.

Yes, I am! In the dark. And that's where I've been ever since I glimpsed what's in store for your planet, your entire species. Something so alien to the nature of Time and Space that I was instantly repelled, like an animal retreating from fire, like the fear of falling into the pit of hell. Almost as if something primal was triggered within me.
You're not making any sense, Doctor.
I must
No, Evelyn, no, you must stay with me.
I must

None of this makes any sense, Tanya. Does a door suspended in the middle of space make sense? It's not about the reasonable and the rational. I think it's something outside all that. Contrary to all the laws of Time and Space, that's what scares me like nothing ever has before. And I have to face it and defeat it. I realise that now. I ran away from it once, but I'm not going to do it again.
Here they come, Captain.
So, if you're going to order me shot, just get on with it. What are you doing?
I'm helping you with Evelyn. Come on.
Thank you, Tanya.
There's just one thing, Doctor.
What is it?
Come back, will you?
Yes, I will. I promise you.
Maybe this isn't time for reason. I believe you. Go!
Tardis door closes.
I must, I must

No, no. It's all right. You'll be all right in here. There. There, there. There you are. You're all right now. You're all right now, aren't you? All right? Now, I'm going to let you go, and you're going to be all right. There.
No! I must
Sit. You won't be able to get through that door.
Bangs on Tardis door.
I must!
Not ever, so there's no use trying.
I must. I must.
What is it? Evelyn? What is it, eh? What's so powerful? What has such a hold on your mind that
Doctor?
You're back.
Did I go anywhere?
You wanted to. Do you remember? Evelyn?
Oh dear. Oh dear me.
It's all right, you're safe now.
Time's End.
What?
Time's End.
Is that what you saw?
No. What I saw was, was
I think I'd better make you a cup of tea.
No, no thanks. No, I'll be all right.
All right.
Just let me sit down.
All right. You sit down, and I'll set the course. 7th of September 1952, Earth, England, Stapley Moor.
The Tardis dematerialises.
Time's End.
Time's End. It can't be. That's just a legend.
That's what I heard, over and over again. And something, something else. I can't remember.
Who was saying it?
Faces. So many faces.
All of them saying that? Time's End?
No, just screaming. Screaming. Terrible screaming. But I remember
It's all right, it's all right. It's gone. You're safe now.
But it hasn't gone. It's still out there, isn't it?
Over two hundred years in the future now. We're approaching 1952 and we're about to land.
The Tardis materialises.
Are we there? Stapley Moor?
Creaking noise.
What was that?
It's as though the Tardis is moving. Are you sure we've landed?
Yes, certain of it. Let's have a look on the scanner. Ah ha. We've handed on a train. A moving train.
The same train you heard at the door?
Do you feel up to going outside and taking a look?
No, but we must.
There's no hurry, you know. We could just wait here for a while. It's nearly two hundred and fifty years until the trouble starts, after all.
Are you sure of that?
No. To be honest, I'm not sure of anything any more.
Unnerving, isn't it?
Decidedly. So shall we go?
Doctor.
What is it?
There was a mouth.
A mouth?
That's what I remember. Around all the screaming faces. It was like a gigantic mouth, wide open, and that's where the words were coming from. I Know, doesn't make sense.
No, maybe not. Maybe not yet, at any rate. Which makes me wonder
What?
What exactly is waiting for us out there.
Train whistle blows.

(sigh) Twenty four across, seven letters. A no-win situation. Something R, something N, something something something. What do you reckon, Palmer? Huh. I always ask, you never answer. Am I that bad an assignment? I'll take that as a yes, then, shall 1? Why should I expect you to change the habit of a lifetime? Feel free to fall asleep. I'm sure it's past your bedtime. And all this banter we're having is wearing me out. No, hang it all. Sorry to disturb you, old chap, but I've been meaning to ask you this for some months. Is it just me you won't talk to, or have you never talked to any of your charges? Oh, good. I was right. I did a little equation that predicted that response. Well, when I say predicted, I mean that I calculated the probability was very high that you'd, surprise, surprise, say
nothing. And there you are, Palmer. Well done. An monument to mathematical certainty.
Footsteps.
Well, I never. There's a random factor beyond my equation.
Connecting door opens and closes.

Or was I imagining it? No, I saw your eyes flicker. Gave yourself away, didn't you, Palmer. You saw that old lady too, didn't you? Admit it. Oh, what are you going to do then, Palmer, eh? Can't have old ladies wandering around on our train, can we? I mean to say, she might be a Russian spy, or Chinese. Didn't look Chinese though, did she. Or Russian for that matter. Probably the lack of fur hat. Cunning disguise, eh? No fur hat. Ingenious. What will the KGB think up next. Am I annoying you yet, Palmer? Am I? Go on, I bet Iam. You see, I've introduced a new factor into my equation. It's A. If A equals annoyance, then, well, you know the sort of thing. A simple shut up Trevor will suffice. Go on, be a devil. No? So, what are you going to do, eh?
Anyone your end of the train?
(laughs) The uniform suits you. Bit short in the leg.
Hmm, well, found it in the guard's van. Although why the guard would keep a spare there I've no idea. Especially since there doesn't appear to be a guard on board at all.
I didn't see one.
So, an empty night train with
Ah, I didn't say it was empty.
But I thought you
No, no, no, no, no. I was merely distracted by your sartorial elegance. There are two people in one of the first class compartments back there.
Ah, I see. Who were they? Did they see you?
Well, I walked right past them, so I suppose they must have seen me.
Door slams.
Is that one of them?
Yeah. Doesn't look very friendly, does he?
No. (Yorkshire accent) Er, tickets please, sir.
Evelyn giggles.
(sotto) Shut up. (accent) I'll be needing to see your tickets if you don't mind, sir.
What are you doing on this train?
Well, just doing me job, sir.
It's not usual, but here you are.
Thank you. Oh, oh, oh yes, sir. Thank you.
All right?
Oh yes, sir. Thank you.
What's she doing here?
I beg your pardon?
Bit late for you to be out, innit, love? Where did you get on?
Guard, are you going to stand there and allow this ruffian to interrogate me in this brusque manner?
Er, oh, well, ma'am, I think it's probably best.
What? Do you indeed?
Er, yes.
Oh. Well, er well, not that it's of any of your business, young man, but I joined the train at er Stapley er
Moor. She got on at Stapley Moor.
Yes, that's right. I knew that. It's just that I'm getting a little forgetful in my old age.
Must be.
Yes. Well, indeed.
Funny.
Well, charming.
No, funny. 'Cos this train doesn't stop at Stapley Moor.
Doesn't it?
You should know that.
Oh, I do, but it did tonight.
Did it?
Didn't you notice? Yeah, didn't you hear? The signal bell. We encountered a red signal, I think. Yes, yes, that was it. Red signal.
(sniffs) Maybe. (leaves)
Phew. How did you know the train had stopped at Stapley Moor?

(normal) I didn't. I just gambled that the station signal bell might be significant. Remember, through that door I heard the train pulling into a station. Maybe this is the only night this train ever stopped at Stapley Moor. At any rate, even if it didn't stop there, our friend clearly wasn't sure. My guess is he's travelled this route quite a few times. He's stuck in a routine, not really concentrating.
Unsavoury sort of chap, wasn't he?
Unsavoury, but important.
Important?
Those weren't rail tickets he showed me. They were War Office travel warrants, signed by the Secretary of State himself.
That would be Anthony Head, in Churchill's government.
The War Office?
It seems our only two legitimate passengers are on a mission of national importance.
I wonder what that could be?
Indeed. But everything in 2197 pointed us here, to this train, on this date.
And if this is going to make any sense at all, we have just two suspects.
Who you are going to question.
Me? Why me?

A lonely old lady on a night train? Surely you're in need of some company? I've already seen their warrants. I haven't got an excuse to go in there. Anyway, I need to make certain we're on the right train.
Let's hope his friend is a bit more sociable that he is.

Oh, all right, I give up. Who was she? You know, the Russian spy mistress without a fur hat. God, you're an annoying ape, Palmer. An ape, do you hear me? An ape! Ooo, 000, ooo. I know you can talk, I heard you on the phone once. Yes, didn't know that, did you. That time we were stuck at the bus depot. Yes, sir, no, sir, three bags full, sir. We're stuck at a bus depot, sir, and I hate Trevor Ridgley, sir.
Compartment door opens and closes.
Oh, hello.
Hello, dear. I do hope you don't mind if join you. It's a bit lonely out there.
Er, no, I'm sure we don't mind. Do we, Mister Palmer? Don't mind him, he never talks.
Really? Well, he was talkative enough to cross-question me out there in the corridor, weren't you, Mister Palmer?
I think it's just me he doesn't talk to. I'm sorry, I haven't introduced myself. Er, Trevor Ridgley. Honoured to meet you, Mrs er?
Doctor Evelyn Smythe.
Doctor? Ooo, how interesting. I didn't know they needed any doctors.
They?
At the base.
The base? Oh, I see.
I presume that's where you're heading.
Oh yes, of course. Aren't we all?
Can I see your ticket?
Well, I never. Will wonders never cease? Palmer, do you have a temperature?
Ticket, Doctor Smythe.
I'm afraid I gave it to the guard.
Right. (leaves)
Oh! Well, really. How rude.

Oh, don't be too hard on him. I'd be very surprised if anybody had taught Palmer that you don't leave a lady's presence without first excusing yourself. And count yourself lucky. At least he spoke to you.
I wonder where he's going?
So, you're a medico, then.
I beg your pardon? Oh, I see. No, no, no. My doctorate is in History.
History? I didn't know they needed historians. Still, nothing should surprise me about that place. None of us knows what the other is working on.
Yes, it does seem a very odd way to run a, a base, doesn't it?
From what I've heard, Hill Langton is no different from any of the others. It's all hush-hush
nonsense, but what can you do? We've got the brains and our country needs us. Not really ina position to turn them down, are we.
I suppose not.
Besides, I've heard some pretty murky stories about what happens if you don't do what they want you to.
Really?
Yes. Probably just a load of old rot, though. I expect the top brass just put those stories about to scare the rest of us into line. Anyway, I'm not a Communist or anything like that. Are you?
Am I a Communist?

Only joking. Oh dear, you look quite spooked, Doctor Smythe. I'm sorry if I've put the wind up you. I do rattle on, I'm afraid. My mother always used to say the only way you'll get a woman, my lad, is to talk her into submission.
Do I look as though I've submitted?
What? Oh. Oh yes, yes, very funny. Yes, awfully good. So, what exactly do you? Oh, what's the matter with me. Shouldn't ask, should I.
Well, not really, no.
No, it's none of our business, is it? Even if our lords and masters are plotting the end of the world.
What were you doing out there?
(Yorkshire) Oh, er, just er polishing the name plate.
What?
Yeah, the good old Ivy Lee. Can't have her name besmirched by coal dust and grime, can we?
Have you got that old bag's travel warrant?
Old? Travel warrant? Oh, yes, yes, oh, I see.
She said she gave it to you.
Oh well, she did. Of course she did, yes.
Well then?
Oh, but I left it in the er, in, in
In what?
In the guard's van. I'll go and get it. You go back to your seat and I'll bring it out.
I'll come with you, thanks all the same.
Oh. Oh yes, yes, yes, all right then. You er come with me. That's just champion, that is.
What's that?
Oh, the crossword? Want a go? Palmer's useless.
No, you've drawn something, there.
Oh, it's just a doodle.
It looks like a spaceship.
Oh, really? Do you really think so?
Yes. Quite, oh, what's the word, futuristic.
Ha, ha! Stupidistic, if you ask me. (both laugh) No, it's just something I'm work, well, not working on, just messing about with. Just a load of rubbish. Relieves the boredom.
It doesn't look like a load of rubbish to me, Trevor.
The idle fantasies of an over-active imagination, that's what my physics lecturer at Oxford used to call it. Trouble is, I can't help myself.
Can't help yourself?
Yes. Whenever I'm not really thinking about anything in particular, I just start scribbling, almost without knowing I'm doing it.
Really?
Yes.
Well, it looks more than just a scribble or two. It looks very detailed.

Well, I've got it all worked out, you see. (opens briefcase) Look, the truth is I spend far too much time on it, but the stuff they're getting me to do on rocket propulsion is just so boring I. Oh, shouldn't talk about work, should I? Promise you won't tell.
Of course, Trevor. We're just talking about your other work.

What? Oh, ha, yes, I see. My flights of fantasy. Yes, you see here? This is the general idea. I was thinking that one day we'll need something, I dunno, far more powerful. I mean to say, I can't believe mankind's destiny's just to lob intercontinental ballistic missiles at each other. One day
we'll have put all that behind us. We'll want to strike out amongst the stars and. Sorry, I'm talking rot, aren't I?
No, no. Not at all, Trevor. It, it's fascinating.
Oh. Oh, thanks. That's very kind of you, Doctor Smythe.
Oh please, please call me Evelyn.
Evelyn. What a lovely name.
Door opens and closes.
What the hell are you doing, if you don't mind my asking, Mister Ridgley?
Is there something the matter, Mister Palmer?
(accent) Oh, there's no need for alarm. We're just
That's classified material in that case of yours, Mister Ridgley.
No, it isn't. Well, I mean, it is. There is classified material in my case, but this isn't it. This is just, well
Just your hobby, isn't it, Trevor.
Oh, those stupid bleeding doodles of yours.
Hmm. Very um er imaginative. Enjoying a bit of speculation about the future, were you, madam?
Hmm? I beg your pardon?
Just a load of clap-trap, if you ask me.
Paper being screwed up.
Hey, steady on, Palmer. That's my only copy.
That is not what you're paid for.
It's all right, Trevor. It's all right. I've got it. I've got it.
Evelyn er madam, are you quite all right?
Oh, thank you, Evelyn. That's very kind of you.
Right, you, take me to her travel documents right now.
I think I'll just go and
Evelyn, what are you doing?
Sit down, would you please, madam.
No. If it's all the same to you, I'd rather just go for a little walk.
A little walk? Evelyn.
Since when were you on first name terms?
Oh I er, well, I
There's something going on here and I don't like it. Madam, please sit down.
No! I must, I must
Evelyn.
(normal) Oh no. Evelyn! Evelyn!
Right. You, shut up. And madam, if you don't sit down, I shall have to
No! I must!
Thumps and gasps.
Evelyn!
(laughs) Well, I never.
She's got a right kick on her.
Knocked down by an old lady. You'll never live it down, Palmer.
Excuse me, please. Ow!
Like being hit by a bleeding brick wall.
Would you mind getting off me, Mister Palmer.
What? Oh.
Trevor.
What?
That's your name, isn't it?
Yes, but
Here, your voice has changed.
And if you don't help me, Trevor, a great deal more will change, and not for the better.
What on Earth do you mean?
Those papers she's taken.
What, those
Yes, those papers. What are they?
Nothing at all important, just
It doesn't matter, just tell me exactly what they are, Trevor.
Just a load of nonsense, really.
He's always scribbling away at that rubbish. Anyhow, who the hell are you? You're 5, aren't you.
It doesn't matter who I am. Trevor, the diagrams. They look like spaceship engine designs.
Space?
There's no need to get. They're just doodles. Nothing secret of anything. Just silly ideas I jot down to amuse myself from time to time.
A star drive.
What?
I'm going to need to see your papers.
It was a star drive, wasn't it? I recognise. Did I hear you say it was your only copy?
Wait.
Well, yes, I
No, Evelyn. Evelyn!
Door opens.
Evelyn, what are you doing out here? Come back into the guard's van. Evelyn.
No. No. I must, must
Must what?
Must.
There's no door here. No door into nowhere. There's nowhere for you to go. Look at those papers, Evelyn. Did you look at them? What did you see?
Time's End.

No, it's not Time's End. It's the future. Don't you understand that those scribbles, those idle doodles, they're the seed of mankind's future. Like Leonardo's sketches of helicopters or tanks, way before their time. No one will take any notice of Trevor just now. They'll dismiss him, laugh at him. In 1952 the world was far too preoccupied with devising ways of blowing itself up. Trevor's idea is a tiny seed planted in Time by his idling imagination. Do you see that, Evelyn?
Doctor? Doctor, is that you?
Yes. Yes, it's me, Evelyn. It's the Doctor.
I can't see you. I can't. All I can see is (train whistle) No. No.
What is it, Evelyn? What can you see?
No, no. I must, must
Evelyn, someone, someday, will return to Trevor's ideas. I think someone will find them and see something in them. That's his only copy. You mustn't
Doctor, I can't hear you. I can't hear you. Where are you?
Evelyn, I'm here. Can't you hear my voice? Come back inside the carriage. You must
Screams. I can only hear the screams. Oh God, Doctor, are you there? It is horrible, horrible.
Evelyn, I'm holding your hand. That's me. Do you feel that, hmm? Can you hear me now? Evelyn! Evelyn!
I can hear Time's End.
What? I can't hear you.
Time's End.
No!
Time's End! Time's End!
Time's End!

OSWIN: Master at Arms.
MASTER AT ARMS: Captain, security report over thirty people on their way here. All of them under the influence of that thing.
OSWIN: They'll never get through that bulkhead now.
DOCTOR: I think they'll find a way. I think they'll tear themselves and the bulkhead apart trying to get to that door.
EVELYN: I must
DOCTOR: And I'm not waiting around to see my friend
